_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The one covered process does not meet the requirements of Program 1. It is subject to OSHA's PSM standard.  Therefore, this RMP is written to meet the EPA Program 3 level of compliance.



This program was updated in 2019 ahead of the 5-year anniversary date and to make corrections as necessary.  All prevention program elements have been updated accordingly.



The following areas are addressed in this summary:



1.    Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source

2.    The stationary source and regulated substances handled

3.    The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures 

4.    The accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps

5.    The five-year accident history

6.    The emergency response program

7.    Planned changes to improve safety



A-1     ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES 



California Dairies, Fresno Processing Plant is committed to complying with all of the regulatory requirements of the EPA Risk Management Program. California Dairies, Fresno Processing Plant has developed their Risk Management Plan / Process Safety Management (RMP/PSM) making up the CalARP program to document policies and address the implementation of these regulations. The PSM sections pertain to the prevention of accidental releases and include the process hazard analysis study and procedures for operating, training, maintenance, emergency response, and others. The RMP sections pertain to management systems and include the hazard assessment.



Federal regulations require reporting when there is a release of ammonia exceeding 100 pounds in 24 hours.



State regulations require reporting when there is an accidental release of ammonia or a threat of accidental release of ammonia.  California Dairies, Fresno Processing Plant interprets this regulation at any release that poses a threat of injury above and beyond

minor irritation to anyone.



All releases and near misses are to be recorded using the incident investigation forms.  All releases are to be monitored and all readings recorded.  All releases and near misses are to be reviewed to develop procedures that may prevent future incidents.



Any release of more than 25 ppm may result in immediately shutting down the ammonia systems depending on the location of the release and notifying the refrigeration contractor. The Facilities Superintendent and Safety Director are to be called if not on site for support.  Releases less than 25 PPM shall result in immediately calling the Facilities Superintendent, if not on site, for instructions.



There are additional full-time managers and operational employees at this facility in addition to the Maintenance Manager that have been trained to conduct visual and audible inspections of the ammonia systems on a regular basis. They are instructed to report any condition that could result in an ammonia release immediately.    



A-2    STATIONARY SOURCE ACTIVITIES AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



The original California Dairies, Fresno Processing Plant was built in 1928 and expanded and modified in 1994 and 1996. The covered process provides product cooling, and short-term storage for milk and associated milk products and by-products. The refrigeration system is operated up to 24 hours per day throughout the year to meet production needs.



The facility is located in an industrial area of Fresno County on a contiguous property.  Ammonia is used as the refrigerant in the refrigeration process. The total ammonia inventory in the one process exceeds the Federal and State thresholds.   



A-3     HAZARD ASSESSMENT



The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures. The regulation requires that the Worst-Case Release Scenario use the ammonia quantity in the largest vessel or pipe. 



NOTE: It is important

to consider that the Worst-Case Scenario is extremely unlikely to occur since this scenario does not consider any safety features of the system - in either design or operation. Furthermore as the refrigerant escapes pressure will decrease reducing the release rate. The scenario parameters are established by the regulation to provide uniformity for dialog between the industry, community, and regulatory agencies.



The regulation allows the facility to select the Alternate-Case Scenario.



A-4    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



California Dairies, Fresno Processing Plant Prevention Program is described in the RMP/PSM program elements. The Risk Management Program (RMP) is equivalent to OSHA's Process Safety Management Program (PSM). The Prevention Program implemented by California Dairies, Fresno Processing Plant is essential to help prevent or minimize the effects if a release occurs.



Key objectives of California Dairies, Fresno Processing Plant Prevention Program are briefly described below:



Process Safety Information

Maintain current and complete refrigeration system technical information.  The facility has retained the original manufacturer OEM manuals, equipment drawings, etc. for reference purposes and aid in maintenance activities.



Process Hazard Analysis

Provide thorough team evaluation of the refrigeration system.  The evaluation considers several potential problems including mechanical problems, human errors, and external events (e.g., earthquakes).  All safety recommendations developed by the team are reviewed and addressed by California Dairies, Fresno Processing Plant.  



Standard Operating Procedures

Written procedures and policies that establish how the refrigeration system should be operated.  California Dairies, Fresno Processing Plant shall develop standard operating procedures for the safe and normal operation and shut down of the ammonia refrigeration system. The manufacturer's OEM manual may be used for reference.  The standa

.



A-5    FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There were no reportable ammonia releases at this facility during the last 5 years that meet the standard of State or Federal regulations.  



A-6    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



This facility has trained personnel to implement the Emergency Action Plan developed for this facility for flammables, fire, earthquake, hazardous materials and other emergencies. 



Facility personnel have coordinated with responding outside agencies such as Fresno Fire and Fresno County Environmental Health. The facilities emergency action plan has been coordinated with the community plan which includes these agencies. 



The facility shall coordinate with outside parties through drills. Facility personnel have exchanged data with local environmental authorities, fire and contractors who might assist during an emergency.  In addition, Fire Department personnel have toured the facility on several occasions to get a better understanding of the processes and the facilities during an emergency such as fire, earthquake and or a chemical release.



Detailed plans have been developed to assist responding facility personnel.  Under the best circumstances, all areas (zones) inside the building should be brought under control within 20 minutes of an ammonia release or breakdown, if personnel are on site.  Small releases should be brought under control immediately.  



The plan for all releases is to gain access to the shut down valves and switches for the system.  If the system shut down areas are within the ammonia release area the entire ammonia system may be shut down if appropriate.  The appropriate shut down switches are identified.  



Facility hazardous material personnel do not enter an IDLH condition which is currently 300 ppm for ammonia. Responders are trained to the air purifying respirator level and trained to retreat at the IDLH level.  Facility hazmat team personnel will assist outside agencies during larger releases merely for facility or c

rd operating procedures are annually reviewed and are readily accessible to operators involved in the processes



Training

Certification of refrigeration operators to safely operate the refrigeration system.  California Dairies, Fresno Processing Plant certifies operators following completion of operator training and confirmation of the operator's ability to apply what they have learned



Mechanical Integrity

Prevention is the primary reason regular and scheduled maintenance is performed on the ammonia refrigeration system.  The maintenance schedule shall follow industry RAGAGEP, manufacturer recommendations, and/or industry practice to help maintain the system.  The facility utilizes outside contractors to perform routine and emergency maintenance on the system.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.



Management of Change

These procedures require that all changes (even "replacement in kind") be reviewed to see if there is a possible negative effect. The main categories reviewed are the technical basis for the change, the impact on safety and health, modifications to operating procedures, and authorization requirements for the proposed change.



Pre-Startup Safety Review

Following completion of a change, a pre-startup safety review is required before the system can be started.  This confirms that the following program elements have been updated, revised, or carried out: process safety information, process hazard analysis, training, safety procedures, operating procedures, and verification that construction and equipment are in accord with the design specifications.



Compliance Audit

This audit process is an important tool to confirm whether each of the elements has been implemented and properly documented by California Dairies, Fresno Processing Plant personnel.  California Dairies, Fresno Processing Plant has established a tracking system to address any found deficiencies.



Incident

Investigation

Written procedures and forms are in place detailing how and when the facility must investigate accidental/incidental releases.  The facility investigates releases and near misses that could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia.  Recommendations are addressed and corrected by facility management.  Reports are kept for at least five years.



Employee Participation

Employee involvement is critical to the success of the prevention program.  This is addressed on two levels.  First, refrigeration equipment operators participate in the planning and evaluation of the prevention programs (e.g., process hazard analysis study team, writing and/or reviewing operating procedures, Incident Investigation team, etc.).  This involvement encourages ownership of the Prevention Program and positively affects the operator's day-to-day activities.  



Second, all California Dairies, Fresno Processing Plant employees (direct hires and contract) receive ammonia awareness training.  Additionally, they have access to the RMP/PSM information.  These activities improve the overall safety of the employees. 



Hot Work 

If welding, grinding, or other hot work occurs, a Hot Work permit is required.  The purpose of the permit and the associated hot work procedure is to minimize the possibility of a fire.



Contractor

For maintenance contracts, California Dairies, Fresno Processing Plant has a procedure for selecting a contractor based on the company's experience and safety history.  All contractor training and documentation associated with this element, is managed through ISNetworld.



INJURY AND ILLINESS / ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM

This facility follows the EPA's 40CFR68 Risk Management Plan and OSHA's 29CFR1910.119 Process Safety Management Program.  In addition, the plan satisfies the State of California's Injury and Illness Prevention Program requirements CCR Title 8 3203.

In California, every employer is required by law to provide a safe and healthful wor

kplace to his/her employees. In accordance with the California Code of Regulations, California Dairies, Fresno Processing Plant has an effective written Injury and Illness Prevention Program (IIPP). 

The IIPP is a written plan that covers the following elements:

     Management commitment/assignment of responsibilities 

     Safety communications system with employees 

     System for assuring employee compliance with safe work practices 

     Scheduled inspections/evaluation system 

     Accident investigation 

     Procedures for correcting unsafe/unhealthy conditions 

     Safety and health training and instruction 

     Recordkeeping and documentation 

The IIPP includes procedures that California Dairies, Fresno Processing Plant personnel must put into practice. It is both the employer's and employee's responsibility to control potential workplace hazards and correct hazardous conditions or practices as they occur or are recognized. The program includes a system for personnel to communicate with management on matters relating to occupational safety and health, including provisions designed to encourage employees to inform the management of hazards at the worksite without fear of reprisal.

The safety communications system, one of the elements of the IIPP, is readily available and understandable to all affected employees. The safety communication system includes:

     Meetings 

     Training programs 

     Postings 

     Written communications 

     A system for anonymous notification by employees about hazards 

     Labor/management safety and health committees 

     Tail gate or tool box meetings

In addition to the above, during construction the IIPP requires that Manager's conduct "toolbox" or "tailgate" safety meetings with their crews at least every ten working days to emphasize safety. Managers also need to hold periodic meetings to discuss safety problems and accidents that have occurred.

The completed IIPP is filed and maintained by the Director of Safety and housed electronically

hemical information purposes.  All personnel not trained to respond will evacuate to the meeting areas and be accounted for.



A-7    PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Employees, community safety, the environment and product care are primary concerns.  The prevention program has been updated as part of the 5-year program update and re-submittal process.  Several PHA studies were conducted at California Dairies, Fresno Processing Plant and the study team made recommendations for additional safety.



Refer to the most recent process hazard analysis for the scheduled list of improvements to reduce accidental releases either in process or planned for at this time.
